#  Abstracts

## What is an abstract?

An abstract summarizes  a piece of academic writing. 
The abstract appears in multiple locations. 
Readers typically use it to decide whether or not to read your paper.


## A good abstract

- Summarizes the entire paper  in one paragraph

- Usually about 250-350 words

- Written in the past tense and in the third person

- Entirely new text (not cut and pasted)

## A good abstract ...

- Stands alone

- Includes keywords

- Has concise, clear, specific, carefully edited language

- Understands the audience

- Is not misleading


# Structure

## A few sentences per section (i)

- Introduction = background & the goal of the study

- Method = basic study design

- Results = summary of major findings

- Discussion = interpretation, implications, conclusions


## A few sentences per section (ii)

- Introduction = the state of the art and/or the gap you fills

- Method = Describing what you did

- Results = A statement of the thesis

- Discussion = The implications of your findings


## Useful references

- [Writing an Abstract](https://www.adelaide.edu.au/writingcentre/ua/media/26/learningguide-writinganabstract.pdf)

- [How to write a good abstract for a scientific paper](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC3136027/)
